content.description: Fun steep climbing! Super bouldery crux mid pitch.  Connects two slash features on gently overhanging rock from start to finish, no fluff!
content.location: 60 yards right of “Bury the Hatchet”. Go up a gully, located on the right side of the gully.

climbs.name: Total Eclipse of the Heart
climbs.fa: EC, August 2017 (bolted on August 21, just after Viewing the total solar eclipse)

content.description: A great new addition to a beautiful crag that's already stacked with classics.  Begin with a hard boulder problem (stick clip!) leaving the ground and continue through 5 bolts of fun, unique low-end 5.12 climbing.  Rock over and milk the no hands rest.  Once rested adequately, pull a few entry moves then begin the nearly perfect ladder of pockets (mostly 2-finger) that builds to the crux below the last bolt.  A few moves of easier tech will see you to the chains.
content.location: The only route on the buttress just right of Bighorn Roundup and the Crazy Woman routes. Belay and begin climbing off of the boulder below the first bolt. Stick clip is highly recommended!

content.description:
Begin with some easy climbing on flakes to gain the steeper white rock. Some low 5.12 (I think?) climbing leads into the obvious crux boulder problem surmounting the steep bulge midway up the route. The boulder problem is reachy, very cool and very hard - probably around V7/8. The name is based on my solution to the boulder problem. Traverse left at the end of the boulder problem, milk the rest then tackle the technical (and sharp!) headwall.

I haven't been able to get back and invest the required time to complete this one so I'm opening it up for everyone. Because it hasn't been climbed on much, the upper half is still very sharp.

After I completed bolting this, I headed back to civilization to find out that the bolting issue had blown up and a bolting ban had taken effect for the BigHorns. Maybe the last legally bolted climb in the BigHorns?
content.location: Begins on a 5 foot flake feature just left of the belay platform for Poker Face. Look for the steep white bulge midway up the route. A few hundred feet to the right of Bury the Hatchet.

content.description: Climb thin face features up to the high first bolt (stick clip recommended) and work right into the hanging left-facing corner for a few bolts. Step right around the arete and continue up a variety of fun face features.
content.location: Shepherd's Delight is on the right side of the cliff. Look for a lone, large Douglas fir tree- the route starts on the left side of the tree.

content.description: Continuous edge and pocket climbing all the way to the anchors.
content.location: Right-most route on the Campground Host Wall. About 20 feet right of the large lone tree.

content.description: Steep slab to bulging headwall on excellent pockets. Short but quality!
content.location: Up the dark rock just left of a gold streak. This is the 2nd route from the left on this wall, not counting the pillar on the far left.

climbs.name: Poker Face
climbs.fa: Mark Rolofson, Ken Trout and Marsha Trout 1992

content.description:
According to Trevor Bowman's

Rock Climbs of the Eastern Big Horns

, this route was described by Ken Trout as "small hold torture." I disagree. While there are a few small crimps, I thought this was a fantastic route with a great variety of movement and holds on terrific, dead vertical rock.  Incredibly sustained 5.11+ climbing with almost no easy moves on the entire pitch.
content.protection: 11 bolts to clip and lower anchor. Anchor was replaced/upgraded in July 2019.
content.location:
Poker Face is located on the right side of a clean white arete a few hundred feet right (south) of

Bury the Hatchet

. The obvious, tightly spaced line of ring bolts is Poker Face. Scramble up the small 12ft tower to begin the route. There is potential to hit the tower going to the second bolt so it might not be a bad idea to bring a stick clip.

There is a closed project on the left side of prow and two 5.13s on the overhanging face right of Poker Face.

content.description: Starts of a small ledge about 20' up, scramble in from the right. Great steep pulls on good holds. Merges with Cowpoke (route immediately right) for the last couple bolts.
content.location: Left-hand of two adjacent routes starting off a ledge just left of a flared chimney.

content.description: Enduro cranking on gently overhung stone similar to Hole in the Wall except steeper, thinner, and with one cruxier spot.
content.location: The 2nd route from the left on this taller buttress right of the flaring chimney, shares the first 3 bolts with No Way Out.

content.description: Fantastic climbing! Another limestone classic that looks like crap but is actually quite solid and climbs like a dream. Great pockets, edges and jugs, fun athletic movement, ever steepening, to a "sting in the tail" heartbreaker move below the anchors. Maybe a bit soft for the grade?
content.location: Next route left of Bury the Hatchet.

content.description: Endurance cranking on positive small features with no real crux. Excellent journey!
content.location: The left-most route on this buttress. Just right of a flaring chimney.

content.description: Mostly easier climbing in the first half (one hard move leaving the 2nd bolt) leads to a sustained upper half. Terrific rock and some fun, unique moves. Due to the aspect, this one gets a shade a little longer than the routes on the Crazy Woman and Campground Host Walls. It also has a large tree in front of it so there is some filtered shade throughout the day.
content.protection: 7 bolts to clip and lower anchors.
content.location: Right-most route at the entire crag. About 100 feet right of Sharp Shooter on the Campground Host Wall. Just right of a large dead tree leaning against the cliff.

content.description: Climb the juggy lie-back flake until you're even with the second bolt then traverse left into the business. A couple bolts of hards slab climbing lead to more hard climbing  on pockets and underclings as the angle kicks back to gently overhanging. Just as you're getting really pumped it eases off a touch going to the chains. Great route on terrific rock!
content.protection: 7 bolts to clip and lower anchor. Anchor was replaced/upgraded in July 2019.
content.location: Dementia begins a few feet right of the lone pine tree on the right side of the Campground Host Wall. Look for the line of bolts that climbs within about 5 feet of the tree for most of the pitch. It is currently the third route starting on the right side of the entire cliff.

content.description:
Crazy Woman Right is another forgotten Catlin route. Just like it’s next door neighbor (CW-Left) it was given some attention 25 years later from Mike Williams by adding a few bolts to the LONG run outs (ground fall potential) and giving it some traffic. This route benefited greatly from a recent cleaning and rebolting effort.

Start by climbing the first two bolts of the Marie Antoinette Crack, then punch up the steep head wall where you will find the business, then rest on the slab before doing one final steep section to clip the anchor.
content.protection: 11 SS glue in bolts to rap rings
content.location: This route shares the start with the Marie Antoinette Crack (First 2 bolts) and is located just to the right of Crazy Woman Left. The first bolt is a camouflaged wedge bolt/hanger and the rest of the bolts are glue ins.

content.description: The route was originally bolted by Alex Catlin in 1988. Mike Williams gave it some attention 25 years later, by adding a few bolts to the 20-25’ runout sections. As of June, 2021 the entire line has been rebolted with SS glue in bolts and it has rap rings at the anchor. When rebolting this line, it was evident that this route hasn’t seen much attention. I’m hoping that the fresh hardware will inspire some folks to give it some love!
content.location: This route is located two lines to the right of Bighorn Round Up.

content.description: Start off the ledge 20' up and pull positive edges and pockets on vertical or slighly overhung terrain. Shares the last couple bolts with Poke in Your Pocket (route immediately left).
content.location: Just left of a flaring chimney.

content.description: The face climb just left of Cake and Ice Cream. Also a good warm up.
content.location: 5th route from the right. Heads to the left anchors under the higher big roof.

content.description: Somewhat wandering face climbing to anchors below the right side of the roof. Good warm up.
content.location: 4th route from the right with anchors on the right side of the upper of two big roofs.

content.description: Excellent blunt rib with juggy pulls.
content.location: A blunt, black rib on the right margin of the buttress.

content.description: A fantastic, long, technical pitch that may have a few different crux sections depending on your strengths.
content.protection: 10 bolts to clip and lower anchor.
content.location: Left-most route on the Campground Host Wall. Starts on obvious lie-back crack.

content.description: Crimpy lower bit to a steep, clean headwall. When it seems to blank out, weave right and then back left on good features. Fun, but not as good as its neighbors.
content.location: 3rd route from the left on this shorter wall. Up the fairly obvious gold streak.

content.description:
A seriously sustained endeavor offering the best Wyoming dolomite has to offer. Look for the beautiful, steep, white prow towards the center of the cliff (no trees at the base so it's visible from the road/parking). The feature is obvious and begs to be climbed.

Start with a fun burly lieback and gain a beautiful white prow. Begin busting out hard moves straight up this prow and don't stop 'til you clip the anchors. Great edging, big & powerful movement, and plenty of classic two-finger pockets.

.12b is the original grade, but subsequent climbers have suggested a harder grade.
content.location: The route tackles the obvious steep white prow visible from the road. Look for the line of bolts that begins in a left-facing corner and moves to the right onto the white prow. There are a few more difficult routes just to the right of Bighorn Roundup, but currently all the other routes described on the Crazy Woman Crag mountain project page are well to the left of this.

climbs.name: Bats in Her Belfry
climbs.fa: EC, June 2019 (anchor, last two bolts and minimal cleaning was completed by an unknown party)

content.description: Formerly the "Isis 12a TR" in Trevor Bowman's excellent guidebook to the Eastern Big Horns. Although this looks like a slab climb from below, it does not climb like a slab at all. Some easier climbing will see you to the first bolt (stick clip recommended). Terrific and sustained  climbing from the 2nd bolt to the 6th makes up the meat of the route. A great variety of movement that will test all your vertical limestone skills - crimps, pockets, side pulls and underclings. It could be beneficial to have a double or triple draw hanging on the third bolt.
content.location: Right-most route on the Crazy Woman Wall.

content.description: Offers climbing which is thinner and more bouldery than its neighbors to the right & left. Classic thin (but positive) pockets and edges at the crux with very memorable sequences. This wall is stacked with classics. It was fun to be able to add our own- do them all!
content.location: Between Bury the Hatchet and No Way Out (Rick's Route).
